question_text:
While making desserts for a bake sale, Billy used $\frac{1}{3}$ of a scoop of brown sugar as well as $\frac{1}{6}$ of a scoop of white sugar. How much more brown sugar did Billy use?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ scoops
solution: Find how much more brown sugar was used by subtracting $\frac{1}{6}$ from $\frac{1}{3}$.
You can use 6 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{1}{3}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{1 \times 2}{3 \times 2} = \frac{2}{6}$

Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{2}{6}-\frac{1}{6}=\frac{1}{6}$
Billy used $\frac{1}{6}$ of a scoop more brown sugar.

question_text:
Hoping to be named Salesperson of the Month, Emir called the names from 1/2 of a page of the phone book last week. This week, he called the people listed on another 3/10 of a page of the same phone book. How many pages worth of people did Emir call in all?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ pages
solution: Find the number of pages of people Emir called by adding $\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{3}{10}$.
You can use 10 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{1}{2}$ by 5 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{1 \times 5}{2 \times 5} = \frac{5}{10}$

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{5}{10}+\frac{3}{10}=\frac{8}{10}$
Emir called $\frac{8}{10} = \frac{4}{5}$ of a page worth of people in all.

question_text:
While conducting a chemistry experiment, Walter White used $\frac{2}{3}$ of a liter of methylamine as well as $\frac{1}{6}$ of a liter of phenylacetic acid. How much more methylamine did Walter use?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ liters
solution: Find how much more methylamine was used by subtracting $\frac{1}{6}$ from $\frac{2}{3}$.
You can use 6 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{2}{3}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{2 \times 2}{3 \times 2} = \frac{4}{6}$

Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{4}{6}-\frac{1}{6}=\frac{3}{6}$
Walter used $\frac{1}{2}$ of a liter more methylamine.

question_text:
While preparing his signature dish, Gordon Ramsay used $\frac{3}{4}$ of a tablespoon of truffle oil as well as $\frac{1}{4}$ of a tablespoon of olive oil. How much more truffle oil did Gordon use?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ tablespoons
solution: Find how much more truffle oil was used by subtracting $\frac{1}{4}$ from $\frac{3}{4}$.
You can use 4 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{3}{4}$ by 1 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{3 \times 1}{4 \times 1} = \frac{3}{4}$

Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{3}{4}-\frac{1}{4}=\frac{2}{4}$
Gordon used $\frac{1}{2}$ of a tablespoon more truffle oil.

question_text:

Tony used $\frac{1}{3}$ of a gram more palladium.

question_text:
While mixing bat-signal fuel, Batman used $\frac{2}{3}$ of a container of phosphorus compound as well as $\frac{1}{4}$ of a container of ignition fluid. How much more phosphorus compound did Batman use?

_ containers

You can use 12 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{2}{3}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.

Now subtract the fractions. Subtract the numerators and keep the denominators the same.

Batman used $\frac{5}{12}$ of a container more phosphorus compound.

question_text:
Hoping to complete their mission, Thanos covered $\frac{1}{2}$ of a unit of the cosmic power from the Power Stone. Then, they covered another $\frac{3}{10}$ of a unit of the same cosmic power from the Space Stone. How many units worth of cosmic power did Thanos cover in all?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ units
solution: Find the total cosmic power covered by adding $\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{3}{10}$.
You can use 10 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{1}{2}$ by 5 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{1 \times 5}{2 \times 5} = \frac{5}{10}$

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{5}{10}+\frac{3}{10}=\frac{8}{10}$
Thanos covered $\frac{4}{5}$ of a unit worth of cosmic power in all.

question_text:
Hoping to complete their mission, Gandalf covered $\frac{1}{3}$ of a chapter of the Middle-earth history tome yesterday. Then, they covered another $\frac{1}{6}$ of a chapter of the same Middle-earth history tome today. How many chapters worth of Middle-earth history tome did Gandalf cover in all?
Write your answer as a fraction or as a whole or mixed number.
_ chapters
solution: Find the total Middle-earth history tome covered by adding $\frac{1}{3}$ and $\frac{1}{6}$.
You can use 6 as the common denominator.

Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{1}{3}$ by 2 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{1 \times 2}{3 \times 2} = \frac{2}{6}$

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{2}{6}+\frac{1}{6}=\frac{3}{6}$
Gandalf covered $\frac{1}{2}$ of a chapter worth of Middle-earth history tome in all.

question_text:

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{1}{4}+\frac{2}{4}=\frac{3}{4}$

$\frac{2 \times 2}{7 \times 2} = \frac{4}{14}$

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{4}{14}+\frac{3}{14}=\frac{7}{14}$
Wonder covered $\frac{1}{2}$ of a area worth of training ground in all.

question_text:

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{2}{8}+\frac{3}{8}=\frac{5}{8}$
Doctor covered $\frac{5}{8}$ of a scroll worth of mystical text in all.
